div.head: A Mean Square Consensus Protocol for Linear Multi-Agent Systems With Communication Noises and Fixed Topologies
div.p: Long Cheng, Zeng-Guang Hou, and Min Tan Abstract-The mean square consensus of linear multi-agent systems with communication noises is studied in this note. Each agent is modeled by a continuous-time linear time-invariant dynamics and the fixed communication topology is described by a digraph. The proposed consensus protocol is composed of two parts: the agent's own state feedback and the relative states between agent and its neighbor agents. Due to the existence of communication noises, the relative states cannot be obtained accurately. To attenuate the noise effect, a time-varying gain vector is applied to the inaccurate relative states. It is proved that: 1) if the communication topology has a spanning tree and every node has at least one parent node, then the proposed protocol can solve the mean square consensus problem if and only if satisfies and ; and all roots of the polynomial whose coefficients are the elements of vector are in the left half complex plane; 2) if the communication topology has a spanning tree and there exists one node without any parent node, then the condition is only sufficient but not necessary; and 3) if the communication topology has no spanning tree, then the proposed protocol cannot solve the mean square consensus problem. Index Terms-Consensus, linear time-invariant, mean square, multi-agent systems, noise.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Recently, the distributed consensus of multi-agent systems (MASs) has attracted considerable attention from the control community due to its fundamental role in other coordination applications. However, most existing papers assume that MASs work in an ideal communication environment, i.e., each agent can receive the information accurately. In practice, communication channels are inevitably interfered by stochastic noises. In the literature, there is a growth of interest in designing proper consensus protocols to reduce the noise effect [1]- [8]. In [1]- [3], Huang and his collaborators first proposed several stochastic approximation type consensus protocols for first-order integral MASs with communication noises under fixed topologies and switching topologies, respectively. In [4] and [5], Li and Zhang further investigated these stochastic approximation type protocols and presented the necessary and sufficient conditions for ensuring the mean square/almost sure average consensus. Based on these results, Liu and Xie studied the mean square consensus of first-order integral MASs with consideration of both communication noises and communication delays [6]. Hu and Feng also provided some results on the mean square leader-following consensus of first-order integral MASs with communication noises [7]. It is noted that the above papers all concentrate on the study of communication topologies and assume that the agent is modeled by a simple dynamics (single integrator). For a comprehensive understanding on the consensus of MASs with communication noises, the effect of agent's dynamics cannot be neglected. Under this research direction, the consensus problem of second-order integral MASs with communication noises was studied in [8]. Extensions to the sampled-data based MASs with switching communication topologies were made in [9]. However, there is still a huge gap between the second-order integral agent and the real-world agent (see a bird-flocking example in [11]). To address this problem, many results were published in the literature to study the consensus of general linear multi-agent systems in the noise-free settings [10]- [14], and it is reported in [10], [11] that these results can find applications in the coordination of multi-vehicle systems. Therefore, it is of great importance to investigate the consensus of general linear multi-agent systems with communication noises.

Motivated by the above discussions, this note studies the mean square consensus of linear MASs with communication noises. Each agent is modeled by a continuous-time linear time-invariant dynamics, and the communication topology of MASs is modeled by a fixed digraph. The proposed consensus protocol employs the information from two aspects: the agent's own state and the relative states with its neighbor agents. Since the relative states are interfered by communication noises, a stochastic-approximation type gain vector is applied to attenuate noise effects, which results in a time-varying stochastic dynamical system. By obtaining the solution to this particular system, it is found that: 1) if the communication topology has a spanning tree and every node has at least one parent node, then the proposed protocol can solve the mean square consensus problem if and only if satisfies and ; and all roots of the polynomial whose coefficients are the elements of vector are in the left half complex plane; 2) if the topology has a spanning tree and there exists one node without any parent node, then the condition is only sufficient but not necessary; and 3) if the topology has no spanning tree, then the proposed protocol cannot solve the mean square consensus problem. This paper is an extension to the previous work [8]. The main improvements lie in that: 1) the agent is modeled by the general linear time-invariant dynamics which includes the second-order integral dynamics considered in [8] as its special case; 2) the consensus protocol is designed in a novel way which cannot be obtained directly from the one proposed in [8]; and 3) although some analysis ideas follow the one proposed in [8], the proof here is much more sophisticated.

The following notations are used throughout this note: ; ; denotes the dimensional identity matrix; denotes the zero matrix with rows and columns; denotes the Kronecker operator; denotes the differential operator with respect to time; denotes the field of complex numbers; denotes the set of natural numbers. For a given variable , denotes the real part of . For a given matrix , denotes its transpose; denotes its determinant. denotes a block diagonal matrix formed by its inputs. For a random variable , denotes its mathematical expectation; denotes its variance.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Let the communication topology of MASs be modeled by a weighted digraph . denotes the node set and denotes the edge set. Node represents the th agent. Edge if and only if there is an information flow from agent to agent . Here node is called the parent node of node , and node is called the child node of node . The set of neighbors of agent is defined by . It is assumed that there is no self-loop in the graph, that is . is called the weighted adjacency matrix of . and . The Laplacian matrix of is defined by where . A path in is a sequence of distinct nodes such that , . A digraph is called strongly connected if there is a path between any two distinct nodes. A directed tree is a digraph where each node, except the root node, has exactly one parent node. A subgraph of is a graph whose node set is a subset of that of , and whose edge set is a subset of that of as well. In addition, if the subgraph's node set equals to the node set of , this subgraph is called the spanning subgraph of . The strongly connected components of a directed graph are its maximal strongly connected subgraphs. has a spanning tree if there is a spanning subgraph of which is a directed tree.

Lemma 1 ( [14], [15]): The Laplacian matrix of a digraph has at least one zero eigenvalue and all nonzero eigenvalues have the positive real part. Furthermore, has only one zero eigenvalue with the associated eigenvector if and only if the digraph has a spanning tree. If a digraph does not have a spanning tree, then the Laplacian matrix has at least two zero eigenvalues. Furthermore, the zero eigenvalue has the same geometric multiplicity and algebraic multiplicity.

Lemma 2: If the digraph has a spanning tree, there exists a left eigenvector of associated with the zero eigenvalue such that and . Furthermore, let be the strongly connected component of such that there is no edge from the node not in to the node in , and let be the index set of nodes in . Then , and , . Proof: This result can be obtained by lemmas 3.1, 3.2, 4.1, and theorem 4.1 in [16].
In this note, every agent is described by the following continuoustime linear time-invariant dynamics: . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
where and are the state and input of the th agent, respectively. It is noted that any controllable -dimensional linear system can be transformed into the Luenberger canonical form defined by (1).

Each agent can obtain the relative states between itself and its neighbor agents through a noisy communication network. Let the interfered relative state received by agent be ( ), where , are assumed to be independent standard white noises, , and are finite noise intensities.
The control objective is to design a distributed protocol to solve the following mean square consensus problem which is directly generalized from the concept proposed in [1], [6].

Definition 1: A control protocol can solve the mean square consensus problem if under this protocol, for the deterministic initial states , there exists a random vector such that and ( ). is jointly determined by the agents' initial states and the communication topology graph. In addition, the protocol is called distributed if the agent's controller only uses its own state and the relative states with its neighbor agents.

The requirement on is necessary. Otherwise, the consensus may be trivially reached without exchanging the information among agents (e.g., design the state-feedback controller for each agent such that its state is stabilized to the origin).

Finally, if some roots of ( 6) are not in the left half plane, then they can only be at the following places: the origin; the imaginary axis; and the right half plane. It is noted that the eigenvalue set of is a combination of zero and the roots of polynomial (6). If polynomial (6) has zero roots, the zero eigenvalue of has the different geometric multiplicity and algebraic multiplicity because of . Therefore, if (6) has zero roots or roots in the right half plane, according to the Lyapunov direct method, there exists at least one initial state such that the corresponding solution is unbounded. If (6) has conjugate imaginary roots, by the knowledge of linear systems, there exists at least one initial state such that the corresponding solution is a periodical function (a combination of sine functions and cosine functions). If the proposed consensus protocol can solve the mean square consensus problem, then for any , , where . From the other side, let . Remark 1: In the noise-free case, ( 12) becomes . Then, by the proof of Theorem 1, the linear MAS reaches a consensus on the vector When the communication noises exist, Theorem 1 shows that this consensus value cannot be deterministically reached. However, it can still be "unbiasedly estimated" by the proposed protocol after several trials because the linear MAS reaches a mean square consensus on the random vector whose mathematical expectation is exactly .

Corollary 1: If the communication topology has a spanning tree and there exists one node without any parent node, then Conditions C1), C2), and C3) are still sufficient for ensuring that the proposed protocol can solve the mean square consensus problem. In addition, the necessities of Conditions C1) and C3) hold as well. However, Condition C2) is not necessary.
Proof: The first part can be directly obtained by the proof of Theorem 1.

To show that Condition C2) is not necessary, one counter example is given as follows. Consider a network composed of two double-integrator agents ( and in (1)). Let the weighted adjacency matrix be and . The noise intensity is set to be . Let and in (2). Then which does not satisfy Condition C2). By L' Hopital law, it can be calculated that . According to (12) and the proof of Theorem 1, it can be obtained that the states of both agents are convergent in mean square to the same random vector with , and . This implies that the mean square consensus can still be achieved.
Theorem 2: If has no spanning tree, then the proposed protocol cannot solve the mean square consensus problem of linear MASs.

Proof: If has no spanning tree, by Lemma 1, it follows that the zero eigenvalue of has at least two different left eigenvectors and such that . Let and . If the proposed protocol can solve the mean square consensus problem, then However, by (5),

In the following part, a simulation example is given to test the proposed protocol. The linear MAS is composed of four agents described by the third-order integral dynamics. The weighted adjacency matrix of the communication topology graph is set as: and all other entries are zero. All noise intensities are 1. The initial state of each agent is set as: , , and . and in the consensus protocol are set as: . According to Theorem 1, states of all agents can reach a mean square consensus. The simulation result is shown in Fig. 1, which validates the theoretical analysis.

div.head: IV. CONCLUSION
div.p: This note considers the mean square consensus of linear multi-agent systems with communication noises and fixed topologies. The contributions of this note lie in that 1) the dynamics of agents is described by a continuous-time linear time-invariant system rather than a firstorder/second-order integral dynamics; 2) a novel distributed consensus protocol is proposed to attenuate the effect of noises based on a timevarying consensus gain; and 3) the capability of the proposed protocol on solving the mean square consensus problem is theoretically guaranteed. div.head: Cooperative Output Regulation of Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems: An Criterion
Chao Huang and Xudong Ye
div.p: Abstract-In this note, the cooperative output regulation problem of heterogeneous linear multi-agent systems is investigated. Our approach is based on internal model and dynamic error feedback among the agents. Under some standard assumptions, the problem is solved by an internal model and a stabilizing controller. We showed that the exo-signal-free system is stabilized if each controlled agent is robust (in the sense of norm) to resist the disturbance measured by the second largest eigenvalue of the graph adjacency matrix. Then the synthesis problem is solved using algebraic Riccati equation. Furthermore, we showed that this condition is a generalization of existing results.
Index Terms-Cooperative control, control, multi-agent systems, output regulation.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Coordination of multi-agent systems has been a hot topic of research over the past decades due to its broad applications in physics, biology, engineering, etc. Fruitful achievement has been made in areas such as consensus [1], [9], [11]; formation control of multi-vehicles, [8], [22]; distributed control of multiple robotics, etc. The key point of such problem is that, in order to accomplish complicated tasks or reach common goals, groups of dynamic agents need to interact with each other and eventually reach an agreement on certain quantities of interest. As a powerful tool in handling such problems, cooperative output regulation of multi-agent systems has attracted broad attention among control groups, such as [12]- [19].

It is well known that there are generally two types of philosophy in tackling output regulation problem in the linear case: the feedforward control and the internal model principle [5]. The feedforward control technique, employed by [16]-[19], requires a feedback gain to make the closed-loop system matrix Hurwitz, and a feedforward gain to drive trajectories of the closed-loop system toward a subspace that renders the regulated output zero. The feedforward gain, as a linear function of the solution of the regulator equations (1) where all plant parameters here are defined in the next section, is dependent on these parameters. As a result, the desired feedforward control has to vary as plant parameters vary. Besides, this method involves introducing a "distributed observer" to asymptotically estimate the state of the exo-system for the agents, thus full state measurement of the exo-system is required in such a framework.
